After bronchial thermoplasty, there were signi /uniFB01 cant improvements in asthma QoL questionnaire measures and reduced exacerbations, healthcare utilization, and days lost from work or education. Reductions in exacerbations and hospitalizations were maintained long term (200).

mphysema despite optimal pharmacological treatment. Both techniques incite in /uniFB02 ammatory reactions to induce reduction of emphysematous areas. BTVA and PLVR treatments have some advantages over EBV: their ef /uniFB01 cacy does not depend on CV, and treatment occurs on a segmental, not lobar, level. Segmental treatment is important, as many patients have intralobar heterogeneity (228). The disadvantage of BTVA and PLVR is their irreversibility.

he pathophysiology of Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (232). Airway submucosal glands are innervated by pulmonary ganglion (233), and stimulation of parasympathetic efferent or sensory afferent (C /uniFB01 bers and stretch receptors) /uniFB01 bers initiate direct (efferent) (234) or re /uniFB02 ex (afferent) (235, 236) mucus hypersecretion. Vagal nerve signaling facilitates disease-related airway hyperresponsiveness, and vagotomy abolishes the effect (237, 238). Cholingergic hyperactivity in Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) causes airway hyperresponsiveness, air /uniFB02 ow limitation, gas trapping, mucus hypersecretion, and exacerbations. Blocking parasympathetic efferent lung signaling may complement bronchodilator therapies for Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

ual-cooled technology to protect the airway epithelial surface, while delivering heat to a targeted depth where pulmonary vagus nerve branches reside. A preclinical study demonstrated that TLD disrupts vagal /uniFB01 bers histologically and produces physiologic changes associated with sensory/motor re /uniFB02 ex signaling (239).

nd the safety of TLD using a 32-W dose (243). AIRFLOW 2 demonstrated that TLD treatment produced fewer airway-related adverse events and fewer Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) hospitalizations (clinicaltrials. gov identi /uniFB01 er: NCT02058459). An international, multicenter randomized sham-controlled TLD trial is evaluating if TLD reduces Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbations (clinicaltrials.gov identi /uniFB01 er: NCT03639051).

heoplasty (RheOx System; Gala Therapeutics) delivers nonthermal energy to ablate airway mucosal cells and reduce goblet cell hyperplasia. content.caption_text: Figure 5. Overview of survival and interventional therapies for advanced emphysema. Adapted from Reference 232. BLVR = bronchoscopic lung volume reduction; CV = collateral ventilation measure by Chartis; EBV = endobronchial valve; Fl 1 =fissure integrity . 90% by HRCT; Fl-=fissure integrity , 90% by HRCT; HRCT=high-resolution chest computed tomography; LVRC=lung volume reduction coil; LVRS = lung volume reduction surgery; VA = vapor ablation.

CT-tobody divergence describes differences in targeted lesion locations identi /uniFB01 ed preprocedurally by HRCT and its location during bronchoscopy. CT-to-body divergence is more important than nodule size in adversely affecting diagnostic yield and a crucial barrier to ablation (2). The following modalities have been developed to address this obstacle; however, none of the technologies have been directly compared for diagnostic yields or cost effectiveness.

EBUS. Launched in 1999, rEBUS (Olympus Corp.), which uses a /uniFB02 exible catheter and rotating ultrasound transducer to produce 360 8 ultrasound images, was /uniFB01 rst used to guide transbronchial lung biopsy (3). During bronchoscopy, the 20-MHz mechanical probe is inserted through a guide sheath into the lung periphery. Figure 1 shows a typical ultrasonographic image.

EBUS is the most commonly used real-time technique to con /uniFB01 rm a lesion during diagnosis and probe placement during therapeutic interventions. However, discordance has been reported for diagnostic yields among studies.

Fielding studied 29 subjects with mean lesion size of 12.2 ( 6 4.2) mm; 41.4% had absent CT bronchus sign. In 96.6% of cases, target was reached and samples were obtained (75). CT-tobody divergence describes differences in targeted lesion locations identi /uniFB01 ed preprocedurally by HRCT and its location during bronchoscopy. CT-to-body divergence is more important than nodule size in adversely affecting diagnostic yield and a crucial barrier to ablation (2). The following modalities have been developed to address this obstacle; however, none of the technologies have been directly compared for diagnostic yields or cost effectiveness.

EBUS. Launched in 1999, rEBUS (Olympus Corp.), which uses a /uniFB02 exible catheter and rotating ultrasound transducer to produce 360 8 ultrasound images, was /uniFB01 rst used to guide transbronchial lung biopsy (3). During bronchoscopy, the 20-MHz mechanical probe is inserted through a guide sheath into the lung periphery. Figure 1 shows a typical ultrasonographic image.

EBUS is the most commonly used real-time technique to con /uniFB01 rm a lesion during diagnosis and probe placement during therapeutic interventions. However, discordance has been reported for diagnostic yields among studies.

ased registration technique aligns virtual images with live bronchoscopic video. Once near the target, the lesion shape is overlaid onto the airway wall to provide biopsy guidance (Figure 2). aralysis, and higher inspired O2, respectively. The latter results in atelectasis and creates CT-to-body divergence. CT-tobody divergence describes differences in targeted lesion locations identi /uniFB01 ed preprocedurally by HRCT and its location during bronchoscopy. CT-to-body divergence is more important than nodule size in adversely affecting diagnostic yield and a crucial barrier to ablation (2). The following modalities have been developed to address this obstacle; however, none of the technologies have been directly compared for diagnostic yields or cost effectiveness.

EBUS. Launched in 1999, rEBUS (Olympus Corp.), which uses a /uniFB02 exible catheter and rotating ultrasound transducer to produce 360 8 ultrasound images, was /uniFB01 rst used to guide transbronchial lung biopsy (3). During bronchoscopy, the 20-MHz mechanical probe is inserted through a guide sheath into the lung periphery. Figure 1 shows a typical ultrasonographic image.

EBUS is the most commonly used real-time technique to con /uniFB01 rm a lesion during diagnosis and probe placement during therapeutic interventions. However, discordance has been reported for diagnostic yields among studies.

ased registration technique aligns virtual images with live bronchoscopic video. Once near the target, the lesion shape is overlaid onto the airway wall to provide biopsy guidance (Figure 2). aralysis, and higher inspired O2, respectively. The latter results in atelectasis and creates CT-to-body divergence. CT-tobody divergence describes differences in targeted lesion locations identi /uniFB01 ed preprocedurally by HRCT and its location during bronchoscopy. CT-to-body divergence is more important than nodule size in adversely affecting diagnostic yield and a crucial barrier to ablation (2). The following modalities have been developed to address this obstacle; however, none of the technologies have been directly compared for diagnostic yields or cost effectiveness.

EBUS. Launched in 1999, rEBUS (Olympus Corp.), which uses a /uniFB02 exible catheter and rotating ultrasound transducer to produce 360 8 ultrasound images, was /uniFB01 rst used to guide transbronchial lung biopsy (3). During bronchoscopy, the 20-MHz mechanical probe is inserted through a guide sheath into the lung periphery. Figure 1 shows a typical ultrasonographic image.

EBUS is the most commonly used real-time technique to con /uniFB01 rm a lesion during diagnosis and probe placement during therapeutic interventions. However, discordance has been reported for diagnostic yields among studies.

ased registration technique aligns virtual images with live bronchoscopic video. Once near the target, the lesion shape is overlaid onto the airway wall to provide biopsy guidance (Figure 2). Blocking parasympathetic efferent lung signaling may complement bronchodilator therapies for Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

aralysis, and higher inspired O2, respectively. The latter results in atelectasis and creates CT-to-body divergence. CT-tobody divergence describes differences in targeted lesion locations identi /uniFB01 ed preprocedurally by HRCT and its location during bronchoscopy. CT-to-body divergence is more important than nodule size in adversely affecting diagnostic yield and a crucial barrier to ablation (2). The following modalities have been developed to address this obstacle; however, none of the technologies have been directly compared for diagnostic yields or cost effectiveness.

EBUS. Launched in 1999, rEBUS (Olympus Corp.), which uses a /uniFB02 exible catheter and rotating ultrasound transducer to produce 360 8 ultrasound images, was /uniFB01 rst used to guide transbronchial lung biopsy (3). During bronchoscopy, the 20-MHz mechanical probe is inserted through a guide sheath into the lung periphery. Figure 1 shows a typical ultrasonographic image.

EBUS is the most commonly used real-time technique to con /uniFB01 rm a lesion during diagnosis and probe placement during therapeutic interventions. However, discordance has been reported for diagnostic yields among studies.

eal-time imaging with steerability. Diagnostic yields of the combined procedure are greater than rEBUS or ENB alone. Others have con /uniFB01 rmed this /uniFB01 nding (7). An opportunity exists to improve rEBUS imaging, especially semisolid lesions, to enhance diagnostic accuracy (8).

ased registration technique aligns virtual images with live bronchoscopic video. Once near the target, the lesion shape is overlaid onto the airway wall to provide biopsy guidance (Figure 2). rticulation (72 -74). First use in humans has been reported in 15 patients (73). Biopsy samples were taken from 93% of subjects with lesions 2.6 mm in diameter; the closest edge was 0.6 mm from the pleura. Cancer was con /uniFB01 rmed in 60% of lesions; time to biopsy was 45 minutes in the /uniFB01 rst /uniFB01 ve cases and 20 minutes in the last nine. Another robotic device (Ion Endoluminal System; www.intuitive.com/ ion) received U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) clearance in August 2019 (https://www.therobotreport.com/ionlung-biopsy-intuitive-surgical-fda/). It has Fiber Optic RealShape technology with ultrathin and maneuverable catheters that navigate to the lung peripheral with maintenance of catheter stability. Fielding studied 29 subjects with mean lesion size of 12.2 ( 6 4.2) mm; 41.4% had absent CT bronchus sign. In 96.6% of cases, target was reached and samples were obtained (75). An overall diagnostic yield of 79.3% was reported, with 88% yield for malignancy.
